questions.text: Match the images of IOL malpositions with their names: Image Syndrome a. 1. Sunrise syndrome b. 2. Lost lens syndrome c. 3. Sunset syndrome
questions.explanation:
Name

Malposition

Sunset syndrome

Inferior subluxation of IOL

Sunrise syndrome

Superior subluxation of IOL

Lost lens syndrome

Complete dislocation of an IOL into the vitreous cavity

Windshield wiper syndrome

When a very small IOL is placed vertically in the sulcus the superior loop moves to the left and right, with movements of the head

questions.text: Toric IOLs are specifically designed to correct which type of refractive error?
questions.explanation:
Anterior chamber IOL

Iris supported lens
  • Lenses which lie completely in front of iris and are supported in the angle of anterior chamber. (S shaped haptic)
  • Presently, AC-IOL are used in those cases where it is not possible to use PC-IOL (made of PMMA)
  • Eg - Kelman multiflex
  • Lenses are fixed on the Iris, with the help of suture,claws or loops.
  • They have high incidents of post-operative complications.
  • Eg - Singh and Worst’s Iris claw lens

Posterior chamber IOL

Scleral fixated IOL (SFIOL)
  • PC-IOL can rest in ciliary sulcus.
  • Capsular bag fixation of PCIOL is the most ideal method.
  • Eg - C loop type and four loop type.
  • They are preferred in cases of ectopia lentis and inadequate capsular support.
  • The optic of the IOL is placed in the posterior chamber.
  • The haptic is fixed to the sclera approximately 1.5 to 2 mm from the limbus.
  • SFIOL can be performed either with sutures or in a sutureless manner (Yamane technique).

Special function IOL
  • Toric IOL: Designed to correct astigmatism (Option C)
  • Aspheric IOL: Designed to reduce spherical aberrations
  • Aniridia IOL: Designed to cover defects of aniridia or partial iris loss.

Unifocal IOLs are the most commonly used ones having unifocal power. Depending upon the power of IOLs implanted, these can make the patient emmetropic, myopic or hypermetropic

Multifocal lOLs have separate optics to focus for distance and near, so also known as simultaneous vision lenses. These are of 2 types, either refractive or diffractive optics types. These are also called pseudo accommodative IOLs.

Accommodative IOLs exhibit some anterior movement of optic to improve the near vision. Available models of accommodative IOLs are: Crystalens and Synchrony lens

Extended-depth-of-Focus IOL- e.g. Technis Symphony, provides uncorrected distance, intermediate as well as near vision to some extent due to its elongated focus.

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the best formula for intraocular lens (IOL) power calculation after LASIK surgery?
questions.explanation:
SRK (Option A)

Hoffer Q (Option B)

Holladay I (Option D)
  • P= A-2.5L-0.9K
    (L= axial length)
    (K= constant)
  • Normal axial length (24 mm)
  • Short axial length (<22mm)
  • Long axial length ( >24.5 mm)

questions.text: In which scenario is a posterior capsule tear more commonly observed during cataract surgery?

options.label: A
options.text: During phacoemulsification with high energy settings

options.label: B
options.text: During cortical clean-up with a manual irrigation-aspiration technique

options.label: D
options.text: During anterior chamber maintenance with a viscoelastic substance

questions.correct_answer: B. During cortical clean-up with a manual irrigation-aspiration technique

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with a history of hypertension and high myopia undergoes cataract surgery. During the procedure, she suddenly experiences severe ocular pain and a rapid rise in intraocular pressure. Fundoscopic examination reveals a dark red elevation in the choroidal region. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate management step?

options.label: B
options.text: Increase the infusion pressure in the anterior chamber

options.label: C
options.text: Perform immediate vitrectomy to drain the hemorrhage

options.label: D
options.text: Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure

questions.correct_answer: D. Close the surgical wound and monitor intraocular pressure
questions.explanation:
Immediate

Subsequate
  • Closure of the incision with a suture to retain residual viscoelastic in the eye.
  • Diagnosis should be confirmed at the slit-lamp as soon as possible.
  • Acetazolamide to lower intraocular pressure.
  • Intensive topical and systemic steroids to reduce inflammation, with standard postoperative antibiotic treatment and IOP management.
  • Drainage, if subsequent hemorrhage fails to resolve (after 7-14 days, by which liquefaction of blood clot has taken place).
  • Pars plana vitrectomy may be considered when the retina appears adherent or detached.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a condition associated with a shallow anterior chamber?
questions.explanation:
Early Postoperative complications

Late Postoperative complications

  • UGH syndrome (uveitis-glaucoma-hyphema) due to ACIOL
  • Iris prolapse
  • Striate keratopathy
  • Flat anterior chamber
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome: Acute postoperative infection within 24 hours.Inflammatory reaction due to non infectious substances like intraocular solutions used in anterior chamber in surgery
  • Bacterial endophthalmitis: Acute postoperative infection within 4-7 days by Staph epidermidis( CONS)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Late post op endophthalmitis after 6 weeks by propionibacterium acnes
  • Irwin Gass syndrome
  • Retinal detachment
  • Epithelial ingrowth
  • Fibrous downgrowth
  • After cataract/Secondary cataract

questions.text: A 67-year-old man had undergone cataract surgery. He presents with endophthalmitis after 3 days. His infection is severe with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Inflammation of inner structures of the eye (uveal tissue and retina) with exudates in the vitreous, anterior, and posterior chambers. It spares sclera.
  • Acute bacterial endophthalmitis happens 1-7 days post intraocular surgery

M/C causative organism
  • Staphylococcus epidermidis

Presentation

  • Severe ocular pain
  • Redness
  • Lacrimation
  • Photophobia
  • Loss of vision
  • Red and swollen lids
  • Conjunctival chemosis
  • Circumcorneal congestion
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Ring infiltration
  • Yellow necrotic wound edges
  • Hypopyon
  • Oedematous and muddy iris
  • Yellow pupil reflex due to purulent exudation
  • Vitreous exudation which causes amaurotic cat's-eye reflex
  • Raised intraocular pressure initially

Treatment

  • Intravitreal antibiotics:
    • First choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Ceftazidime 2.25 mg
    • Second choice: Vancomycin 1 mg + Amikacin 0.4 mg
  • Topical antibiotics
  • Systemic antibiotics
  • Steroid Therapy
  • Supportive Therapy
  • Vitrectomy - if no improvement in 48-72 hours or if severe infection with vision reduced to hand movements close to the face
  • If blind - no perception of light - Evisceration.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has undergone cataract surgery. He has now returned after 6 weeks with endophthalmitis. What is the most likely organism that caused the infection?
questions.explanation:
Onset

  • After 6-weeks of intraocular surgery

Course
  • Slow, with a panuveitis-like picture

Clinical Features
  • Granulomatous keratic precipitates
  • Inflammatory deposits over intraocular lens (IOL)
  • White capsular plaque
  • Anterior chamber reaction
  • Vitritis
  • Cystoid macular edema (CME)

Response to Treatment
  • May respond to periocular or systemic steroids but usually recurs

Common Causative Organisms
  • Bacterial: Propionibacterium acnes (most common), Coagulase-negative Staphylococcus
  • Fungal: Aspergillus, Candida, and others

questions.text: Soemmering's Ring and Elschnig's Pearls are examples of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Definition
  • M/C postoperative complication following extracapsular lens extraction.

Clinical Types
  • Posterior Capsule Opacification (PCO): Common form of after cataract.
  • Dense Membranous After Cataract: Thick membrane formation.
  • Soemmering's Ring: Thick ring behind the iris, enclosed between capsule layers.
 
  • Elschnig's Pearls: Clustered, vacuolated subcapsular epithelial cells along the posterior capsule.

Treatment
  • ND YAG laser posterior capsulotomy

questions.text: A key advantage of peribulbar anesthesia over retrobulbar anesthesia is:
questions.correct_answer: B. Less risk of globe perforation
questions.explanation:
Features

Retrobulbar block

Peribulbar block

Injection Site

Inside the muscle cone (intraconal)

Outside the muscle cone (extraconal)

Onset of Anesthesia

Faster onset (Option A)

Slower onset

Akinesia (Eye Movement)

Better akinesia due to direct nerve blockade (Option C)

Variable akinesia,may require multiple injections

Risk of Globe Perforation and Optic nerve injury

Higher risk due to proximity to the globe and optic nerve

Lower risk

Hemorrhage Risk

Higher risk of retrobulbar hemorrhage

Lower risk of severe hemorrhage

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding Cystoid Macular Edema?

options.label: A
options.text: Collection of fluid in Henle’s layer

options.label: C
options.text: Antiprostaglandin is both treatment and prevention

questions.explanation:
Definition
  • Collection of fluid in cystic loculi in the Henle's layer of the macula
  • Defect in OPL layer of retina( inner retinal blood barrier break defect)
  • Frequent complication of cataract surgery

Fundoscopy

Honeycomb appearance

Fluorescein Angiography

Flower petal pattern

Prevention

Preoperative and postoperative use of anti prostaglandin eye drops (indomethacin, flurbiprofen, or ketorolac)

Treatment
  • Anterior vitrectomy
  • Steroids
  • Antiprostaglandins

questions.text: What is the common inheritance pattern of hereditary cataracts?
questions.explanation:
Idiopathic

Sporadic cases with unknown etiology.

Hereditary

  • Inherited without Systemic Disorders:
    • Usually autosomal dominant.
    • Genes:
      • Cry-G (crystallins).
      • Connexins.
      • MIP (Major intrinsic protein).
 
  • Inherited with Systemic Disorders:
    • Chromosomal disorders (e.g., trisomy 21)
    • Skeletal disorders (e.g., Stickler syndrome)
    • CNS disorders (e.g., cerebro-oculo-facial syndrome)
    • Renal system disorders (e.g., Lowe's syndrome)

Maternal Factors

1. Malnutrition during Pregnancy: Associated with nonfamilial zonular cataract.

2. Infections: Rubella (50% of cases), toxoplasmosis, cytomegalic inclusion disease.

3. Drug Ingestion: Certain drugs (e.g., thalidomide, corticosteroids) during pregnancy.

4. Radiation Exposure: Maternal exposure to radiation during pregnancy.

Foetal or Infantile Factors

1. Deficient Oxygenation (Anoxia): Due to placental hemorrhage.

2. Birth Trauma

3. Metabolic Disorders: Galactosemia, galactokinase deficiency, neonatal hypoglycemia.

4. Associated with Congenital Anomalies: Down's syndrome, Lowe's syndrome, myotonia dystrophica, congenital ichthyosis.

5. Ocular Diseases: Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV), aniridia, anterior chamber cleavage syndrome, retinopathy of prematurity, lenticonus posterior, microphthalmos.

6. Malnutrition in Early Infancy

questions.text: Doctor noticed leukocoria in a 3-month-old baby during a routine examination and the eye appeared as shown below. Choose the least appropriate statement regarding the most likely diagnosis.

options.label: A
options.text: Most common type of congenital cataract

options.label: B
options.text: Commonly inherited as autosomal dominant trait

options.label: C
options.text: Usually zone of fetal nucleus is involved

questions.correct_answer: A. Most common type of congenital cataract
questions.explanation:
Polar cataracts

Anterior polar cataract:

  • Usually associated with persistent pupillary membrane.
  • Non-axial, stationary, asymptomatic.

Posterior polar cataract:

Onion ring / whorled appearance

Associated with :

  • mittendorf dots
  • PHPV
  • PITX 3 Mutation

Congenital nuclear cataracts

Cataracta centralis pulverulenta:

  • Powdery opacity at the center of lens.
  • Usually does not cause vision problems.

 

Lamellar cataract: (zonular cataract)

  • Most common congenital cataract affecting vision
  • Infantile cataract <1 yr child
  • Associated with genetic and environmental causes like vitamin-D deficiency (Option D), congenital rubella syndrome ( but m/c in this is pearly white cataract)
  • Inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. (Option B)
  • Zone of the fetal nucleus is involved. (Option C)
  • Radial opacities (Riders) are seen.

Sutural cataract:

  • Punctate opacities scattered around Y-sutures
  • Patterns: Floriform, Coralliform, Dendritic sutural

Generalized cataracts

Coronary cataract:

  • Adolescent onset cataract
  • Numerous club-shaped opacities in the periphery

Blue dot cataract (cataracta-punctata-caerulea):

  • Most common type of congenital cataract (Option A)
  • Developmental cataract (seen > 1 year child)
  • Does not cause vision problems
  • Associated with Down’s syndrome

Total congenital cataract (TORCH infections)

questions.text: An infant with leukocoria presents with recurrent gastrointestinal infections and developmental regression. Bilateral eye examination revealed the following. Choose the most appropriate next step in evaluation.

options.label: A
options.text: Serum estimation of glucose, calcium, and phosphorous levels

options.label: B
options.text: Estimation of antibody titers for infections

options.label: D
options.text: Urine assay for the presence of reducing substances

questions.correct_answer: D. Urine assay for the presence of reducing substances
questions.explanation:
Description
  • Inborn error of galactose metabolism.

Description and types

  • Classical Galactosaemia: deficiency of galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GPUT).
  • Non-classical type: Galactokinase deficiency

Characteristic Features
  • Frequently leads to bilateral cataract formation.
  • Cataracts often present as oil droplet central lens opacities.
  • Recurrent infections with Escherichia coli.
  • Mental retardation/developmental delay.

Management and prognosis
  • Avoidance of milk and milk-based products.
  • Cataract changes are reversible.



 

Blood analysis
  • Levels of blood glucose, calcium and phosphorus to rule out Hyperglycemia and Hypocalcemia. (Option A)
  • Red blood cell transferase and galactokinase levels - for Galactosemia.
  • Antibody titres for infections such as toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus and herpes simplex virus (TORCH) and hepatitis B virus. (Option B)
 

Urine analysis
  • Urine assay for reducing substances - for Galactosaemia. (Option D)
  • Screening for amino acids in the urine - if Lowe syndrome is suspected. (Option C)
  • Blood in urine - Alport syndrome
  • Estimation of copper in urine - Wilson disease

questions.text: A 1-month-old infant is diagnosed with a dense unilateral cataract. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: Delay surgery until the child is 1–2 years old to reduce surgical risks

options.label: C
options.text: Prescribe glasses and monitor the cataract progression

options.label: D
options.text: Wait until the child develops strabismus before considering surgery

questions.explanation:
Timing of Surgery
  • Unilateral cataracts: as early as possible. (Option B)
  • After 1 month of age for bilateral cataracts. (Option A)

Surgical Technique
  • Small, ideally 1–1.5 mm limbal incisions.
  • Posterior capsulorhexis with pars plana vitrectomy is done additionally to reduce the risk of After-cataract.

Optical Rehabilitation
  • Contact lenses/glasses: for children below 2 years age
  • IOLs: Generally preferred in children above 2 years age
  • Foldable hydrophobic acrylic IOLs are preferred over PMMA.
  • Always placed with undercorrection.

questions.text: A newborn presented with the following findings. There is a positive maternal history for fever during the first trimester of pregnancy. Which among the following is least likely to be seen in this newborn?
questions.explanation:
Cause
  • Maternal rubella infection acquired in 1st trimester

Clinical Features

a. Ocular Defects:

  • Congenital cataract (2nd most common manifestation)
  • Salt and pepper chorioretinopathy (most common feature)
  • Microphthalmia (Option C)
  • Cloudy cornea
  • Poorly dilating pupil

b. Ear Defects: Sensorineural hearing loss (Option D)

c. Cardiovascular Defects:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (Option A)
  • Pulmonary stenosis
  • Ventricular septal defects

Diagnosis
  • RT-PCR/IgM antibody titres

Prevention
  • Administration of rubella vaccine at least three months before pregnancy.

 
  • Congenital Rubella syndrome
  • Congenital Syphilis
  • Myotonic dystrophy
  • Retinitis pigmentosa sine pigmento
  • Leber’s amaurosis

questions.text: A school-going child is diagnosed with a connective tissue disorder characterized by abnormalities of the eye, short stature, brachydactyly, joint stiffness, and cardiovascular defects. Which among the following is incorrect regarding the likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Follows autosomal recessive mode of inheritance

options.label: D
options.text: Usual age of presentation is 5-10 years

questions.correct_answer: B. Associated with supero-temporal lens dislocation
questions.explanation:
Marfan's Syndrome

Autosomal dominant

B/L Supero-temporal dislocation, Megalocornea

Arachnodactyly, long limbs, hypermobile joints, cardiovascular defects

Homocystinuria

Autosomal recessive

Infero-nasal dislocation

A/w zonular breaks and hence loss of accommodation

Detection of homocysteine in urine using the sodium nitroprusside test.

Weill-Marchesani Syndrome

Autosomal recessive (Option A)

Microspherophakia, Inferior or forward subluxation of the lens


 

Short stature, brachydactyly, joint stiffness, cardiovascular defects.

Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome

Lens subluxation, blue sclera, Hyperextensible joints

Stickler Syndrome

Liquified vitreous, retinal detachment, Pre-senile cataract

Oro-facial abnormalities, arthropathy
 

Sulphite Oxidase Deficiency

Autosomal recessive

Ectopia lentis, Progressive muscular rigidity

Death usually by 5 years of age

questions.text: Which of the following is the thinnest part of the lens capsule?
What are the steps involved in FLACS?

options.label: A
options.text: Capsulorrhexis → Corneal Incision → Lens Fragmentation → IOL implantation

options.label: B
options.text: Corneal Incision → Capsulorrhexis → Lens Fragmentation → IOL implantation

options.label: C
options.text: Capsulorrhexis → Lens Fragmentation → Corneal Incision → IOL implantation

options.label: D
options.text: Corneal Incision → Lens Fragmentation → Capsulorrhexis → IOL implantation

questions.correct_answer: C. Capsulorrhexis → Lens Fragmentation → Corneal Incision → IOL implantation

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents for cataract surgery in her right eye. She has moderate cataract density with some nuclear sclerosis and a clear cornea. She expresses a strong desire for a procedure that minimizes recovery time and provides optimal visual outcomes. Which of the following statements accurately reflects the advantage of Phacoemulsification Over Manual SICS?

options.label: A
options.text: Manual SICS typically requires a smaller incision compared to Phacoemulsification.

options.label: B
options.text: Manual SICS allows for faster visual recovery compared to Phacoemulsification.

options.label: C
options.text: Manual SICS is less suitable for very hard cataracts compared to Phacoemulsification.

options.label: D
options.text: Manual SICS usually results in a higher level of postoperative astigmatism compared to Phacoemulsification.

questions.correct_answer: D. Manual SICS usually results in a higher level of postoperative astigmatism compared to Phacoemulsification.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Manual SICS

Phacoemulsification

Procedure Type

Extracapsular Cataract Extraction (ECCE)

Extracapsular Cataract Extraction (ECCE)

Incision Type

Self-sealing, valvular, sclerocorneal tunnel incision

Self-sealing, valvular, sclerocorneal tunnel incision or clear corneal incision.

Anesthesia

Local anesthesia (can be performed under)

Local anesthesia (can also be performed under topical anesthesia)

Nucleus Removal Method

Manually extracted through the incision after being maneuvered out of the capsular bag

Fragmented using an ultrasonic probe and then aspirated

Suitability

(Option C)

Suitable for all cataract densities, including very hard cataracts

Typically requires a smaller incision, less suitable for very hard cataracts

Visual Recovery

(Option B)

Slower visual recovery, delayed return to optimal vision

Faster visual rehabilitation due to smaller incision and reduced tissue manipulation

Astigmatism

(Option A)

Higher levels of surgically induced astigmatism, larger incision

Less postoperative astigmatism due to smaller incision size

Complication Risks
  • Lower risk of nuclear drop
  • Higher risk of postoperative pain and inflammation, hyphema and conjunctival congestion
  • Lower risk of postoperative pain, conjunctival congestion, hyphema and inflammation

Overall Accessibility

More accessible due to cost-effectiveness and versatility

Preferred in settings with better resources and where faster recovery is prioritized

questions.text: Which of the following steps is used to maintain the depth of the anterior chamber and protect the corneal endothelium during Conventional ECCE?
questions.explanation:
Surgery

Site of incision

Size of incision

Conventional ECCE

At the limbus

8-10mm

SICS

Sclera

5-7mm

Phacoemulsification

Cornea

2.2-3.2mm

Microincision (MICS)

Cornea

<1.8mm

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with diabetes presents with rapidly worsening vision. Upon examination, the ophthalmologist notes the presence of bilateral, snowflake-like white opacities in the cortex of the lens. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Shield cataract

Christmas tree cataract

Snowflake/snowstorm cataract

Atopic dermatitis

Myotonic dystrophy

Diabetes mellitus

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents with decreased vision in his right eye following a blunt trauma a few weeks ago. On examination, feathery opacities are noted. What is the most likely type of cataract this patient has developed?
Match the type of cataract with the etiology Type of cataract Etiology a. Posterior subcapsular 1. Glassblowers b. Anterior subcapsular-granular 2. Miotics c. Posterior cortical 3. Steroids

A 30-year-old male with retinitis pigmentosa has developed a cataract as a complication. Which of the following is a feature of his cataract? Posterior subcapsular cortical cataract Irregular in outline Variable density Breadcrumb appearance Polychromatic luster Diffuse yellow haze in the adjoining cortex
questions.explanation:
Definition

Cataracts which develop as a complication of some other intraocular disease

Causes

(mnemonic: UMAR:

-Uveitis

-Myopia

-Angle-closure glaucoma

-Retinitis pigmentosa)
  • Inflammations (Anterior uveitis is the most common cause of complicated cataracts)
  • Degenerative conditions such as retinitis pigmentosa and myopic chorioretinal degeneration
  • Long-standing retinal detachment
  • Glaucoma (primary or secondary)
  • Intraocular tumors in late stages (retinoblastoma or melanoma)

Features

  • Starts as a posterior subcapsular cortical cataract (PSC)
  • Irregular outline
  • Variable in density
  • Slit-lamp:
  • "Breadcrumb” appearance
  • 'Polychromatic luster”, i.e. appearance of iridescent colored particles of reds, greens, and blue
  • Diffuse yellow haze in the adjoining cortex

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of chalcosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition

Specific changes produced by the alloy of copper in the eye

Mechanism

Copper ions from the alloy are dissociated electrolytically and deposited under the membranous structures of the eye

Clinical features

  • Kayser-Fleischer ring (Option A): Golden brown ring due to deposition of copper under the peripheral parts of Descemet's membrane of the cornea
  • Sunflower cataract (Option B): Deposition of copper under the posterior capsule of the lens
 
  • Retina: Golden plaques (Option C) at the posterior pole that reflect the light with metallic luster

questions.text: A 6-month-old girl was diagnosed with galactosemia. An ocular examination has revealed a cataract which developed as a complication. Which of the following statements regarding her cataract is false?
questions.explanation:
Galactosemia

Inborn error of galactose metabolism

Enzyme deficiency

  • Galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase (GPUT)
  • Galactokinase (GK)

Type of cataract

  • Bilateral (Option A)
  • “Oil droplet” (Option B)
  • Central lens (Option C is the false statement)


 

Features

  • May be reversed (Option D)
  • May be prevented if milk and milk products are eliminated at an early stage

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is having difficulty in near vision. The ophthalmologist has prescribed him a convex lens and informed him that it is an age-related physiological condition. Which of the following is an age-related change that would have caused his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Decrease in elasticity of lens capsule

questions.explanation:
Accommodation

The mechanism by which the eyes focus diverging rays from a near object on the retina

Mechanism

When looking at a near object from a far object:

Ciliary muscles contract →Zonules relax→Lens becomes more convex anteriorly

Presbyopia

Physiological insufficiency of accommodation, causing worsening near vision after the age of 40

Causes
  • Decrease in elasticity of lens capsule (Option A)
  • Sclerosis of lens substance (Option B)
  • Reduced ciliary muscle power (Option C)

Treatment

  • Convex glasses for near-work
  • A guide for powers required at various ages:
    • 45 years: + l to +l.25D
    • 50 years: +1.5 to +1.75D
    • 55 years: +2 to +2.25D
    • 60 years: +2.5 to +30D

questions.text: An elderly male diabetic patient came with loss of vision in the left eye associated with pain in the left eye. On examination, the left eye appears red, and visual acuity- Perception of light+ and IOP is raised in the same eye. The patient gives history of blurring and diminution of vision for the past 1 year. The slit lamp examination is given below. Choose the correct diagnosis and appropriate pathophysiology for this patient.
questions.correct_answer: C. Phacolytic glaucoma - Secondary open-angle glaucoma
questions.explanation:
Feature

Phacomorphic Glaucoma

Phacolytic Glaucoma

Pathogenesis
  • Intumescent cataract blocks the pupil.
  • this pushes the iris forward,
  • blocking the anterior chamber angle,
  • leading to angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Leakage of lens proteins from a hypermature cataract clogs the trabecular meshwork.

Causes
  • Intumescent cataract (mature cataract)
  • Anterior subluxation of lens
  • Spherophakia
  • Hypermature (Morgagnian) cataract
  • Obstruction of the trabecular meshwork by lens proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Symptoms are similar to acute primary angle-closure glaucoma.
  • Shallow anterior chamber.
  • Ciliary congestion, dilated pupil, and swollen cataract is visible.
  • Closed anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.
  • Features of acute congestive glaucoma due to high IOP.
  • Deep anterior chamber.
  • Open anterior chamber angle on gonioscopy.

Management
  • Medical Treatment: IV mannitol, systemic acetazolamide, topical beta-blockers.
  • Laser Iridotomy: To relieve angle closure.
  • Surgical Treatment: Cataract extraction with PCIOL implantation.
  • Medical Therapy: To lower IOP.
  • Surgical Treatment: Extraction of the hypermature cataract and PCIOL implantation.

questions.text: An 80-year-old female patient came with complaints of gradual progressive diminution of vision for 2 years in both her eyes. She reports that over the last year, she noticed an improvement in her ability to read without glasses. The following finding is seen on slit lamp examination over the right eye and the left eye has similar opacity. Choose the most appropriate course of management for this patient.

options.label: A
options.text: Advise lifestyle modification and review after 3 months.

options.label: B
options.text: Recommend corticosteroids eye drops and reassess in 6 months.

options.label: D
options.text: Prescribe her rigid gas-permeable contact lenses.

questions.explanation:
Description and Pathophysiology
  • Nuclear cataract/sclerosis- The etiology is nuclear sclerosis.
  • Results from the gradual loss of lens elasticity and transparency due to dehydration, and increase in water-insoluble proteins.

Clinical Features
  • Glare
  • Diplopia
  • Colored Halos
  • Blurred Vision/ Gradual Vision Loss
  • Black spots in front of eyes.
  • Deterioration of vision:
    • In some patients with nuclear sclerosis, near vision improves due to progressive index myopia.
    • Such patients may have improvement in their near-vision glasses.
    • This improvement in near vision is referred to as 'second sight.’

Grading
  • Nuclear Opacity (NO): Ranges from 1 (slight opacification) to 5 (severe opacity).
  • Nuclear Color (NC): Ranges from 1 (amber) to 5 (black).
  • Cataracta brunescens (amber-brown), Cataracta rubra (red), Cataracta nigra (black)

Management
  • Surgical measures: Mainstay of treatment.
  • Cataract surgeries:
    • ICCE (not preferred now)
    • ECCE
    •  SICS (Small Incision Cataract Surgery)
    •  Phacoemulsification (most preferred)
  • Followed by IOL implantation: PC-IOL (Posterior chamber-intraocular lens) is preferred.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with complaints of glare and diminution of vision for 3 months. On examination, you notice the following appearance Choose the correct statement regarding the correct diagnosis.

options.label: A
options.text: The Iris shadow test becomes positive only when the whole cortex is involved.

options.label: B
options.text: Patients see better in dark surroundings.

options.label: C
options.text: Characterized by saucer-shaped opacities in the center of the posterior cortex.

options.label: D
options.text: Vision loss occurs at a late stage.

questions.correct_answer: D. Vision loss occurs at a late stage.
questions.explanation:
Type of Cataract

Characteristics

Visual Impact

Cuneiform Senile Cortical Cataract
  • Wedge-shaped opacities with clear areas in between.
  • Extends from periphery to center.
  • First appears in the lower nasal quadrant. Present in both anterior and posterior cortex.
  • The radial spoke-like pattern of opacities is seen.
  • Visual disturbances are noted at a comparatively late stage (since it starts at the periphery). (Option D)
  • Vision improves in bright light with contracted pupils. (Option B)

Cupuliform Senile Cortical Cataract

  • Saucer-shaped opacities are typically in the central part of the posterior cortex (posterior subcapsular cataract). (Option C)
  • Extends from center to periphery.
  • Causes an early loss of visual acuity.- Due to the involvement of the nodal point
  • Glares seen in PSC
  • Better vision in dim light with dilated pupils.

Stage

Description

Characteristics

1. Stage of Lamellar Separation

Earliest stage of senile cataract
  • Formation of vacuoles and water clefts within the cortex
  • Reversible change
  • Can only be demonstrated by slit lamp examination

2. Stage of Incipient Cataract

Detectable opacities with clear areas present between. Causes visual disturbances.

Cuneiform type:

  • Wedge-shaped opacities, extending from the equator appear as radial spoke-like opacities.

Cupuliform type:

  • Saucer-shaped opacity in the central posterior cortex.

3. Immature Senile Cataract

Progression of opacification
  • Iris shadow visible (clear cortex visible) -Iris Shadow present here due to opacities + clear areas(Option A)
  • Can progress to Intumescent Cataract leading to the shallow anterior chamber.

4. Mature Senile Cataract (aka intumescent cataract)

Complete opacification of cortex
  • The lens appears pearly white
  • Referred to as a "ripe cataract"
  • No iris shadow as the whole lens is opacified with a chalky white color

5. Hypermature Senile Cataract (HMSC)

Advanced stage of cataract beyond maturity

Morgagnian Hypermature Cataract:

  • Cortex liquefies
  • Nucleus sinks to the bottom
  • Bag of milky fluid appearance

Sclerotic Hypermature Cataract:

  • The cortex disintegrates, lens and capsule shrink.
  • Deep anterior chamber
  • Iridodonesis may be present.

questions.text: Which among the following is/are true statements regarding lens proteins? α/β/γ-Crystallins are water-soluble proteins Major intrinsic proteins contribute to lens transparency An increase in crystallins can lead to cataract β/γ-Crystallin family are the largest crystallins
What is the consequence of age-related decline in the Na+-K+ ATPase pump in the lens?

options.label: A
options.text: Increased intralenticular K+ levels and decreased Na+ levels.

options.label: B
options.text: Increased intralenticular Na+ levels and decreased K+ levels.

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased intralenticular Na+ levels and decreased K+ levels.
